clinical_study.brief_title: The Effect of Triple Antibiotic Paste as an Intracanal Medication With an Anti-Inflammatory Drug on Post-Operative Pain of Asymptomatic Uniradicular Necrotic Teeth.
clinical_study.official_title: The Effect of Triple Antibiotic Paste as an Intracanal Medication With an Anti-Inflammatory Drug on Post-Operative Pain of Asymptomatic Uniradicular Necrotic Teeth (A Double Blind Randomized Clinical Trial).

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to determine whether the use of triple antibiotic paste as intracanal medication with an anti-inflammatory drug, compared to a calcium hydroxide will reduce postoperative pain and intracanal bacteria or not in patients with asymptomatic necrotic teeth.

detailed_description.textblock: This trial is aiming to answer a clinical question whether in patients with asymptomatic necrotic teeth, the use of triple antibiotic paste as intracanal medication with an anti-inflammatory drug, compared to a calcium hydroxide, reduce postoperative pain and intracanal bacteria or not? trial design will be Randomized, controlled, double blinded, unicenter, parallel, two-arm, superiority trial with 1:1 allocation ratio.

primary_outcome.time_frame: after 24, 48, and 72 hour from the end of the first visit.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: before and after mechanical preparation (at day 0) and after 72 hour from placement of the intracanal medication.
secondary_outcome.description: Colony forming units per milliliter of blood agar medium

arm_group.description: non setting calcium hydroxide intracanal medication.
triple antibiotic paste with an anti-inflammatory drug

intervention.intervention_name: triple antibiotic paste with an anti-inflammatory drug
intervention.description: Mixture of ciprofloxacin, metronidazole and minocycline.and diclofenac potassium 50 mg (Catafast)

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
1. Subject's age between 18-50 years.
2. Both male and female subjects.
3. Medically free and healthy subjects.
4. Mandibular and maxillary single rooted teeth.
5. Asymptomatic non vital teeth.
Exclusion Criteria:
1. Teeth with acute dentoalveolar abscess.
2. Subjects having more than one tooth that require root canal treatment.
3. Subjects that have taken analgesic, anti-inflammatory or antibiotic drugs during the 10 days prior to the start of treatment.
4. Pregnant females.
5. Subjects with systemic diseases who have endocrine diseases, Infectious diseases or Psychological disturbance.
6. Teeth with periodontal disease or pulp calcification.
7. Subjects taking chronic pain medications.
